title: Binocular eclipse filter for 50mm welding shade

description.text:
This is a two part threaded binocular filter holder. It friction fits on the the end of the binoculars and holds a 50mm welding shade filter.

I made this specifically for a pair of binoculars I already had - Bushnell Falcon 7x35. I don't know if these are the optimal binoculars for eclipse viewing but I thought I would try them.

The holder is not universal but it is easy to model with Autodesk Fusion 360 and the threading feature so is an example if you make a set for a different pair of binoculars. Basically draw two cylinders and add threads. The 50mm shade is held by a 48mm lip on the end of the outer threaded piece.

description.text: I wanted to create a camera roller entirely out of 3D printed parts. I hate going to the hardware store to get nuts an bolts for a 3D printing project. This roller was inspired by the NEWEER camera roller and uses 4 roller blade wheels for rolling on whatever surface you may want to shoot a smooth "slide" on with your camera.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

You can either print the axle model alone with supports, or the short/long axle and glue them together with no need for supports.

Assembly instructions:

place the axle nut into the hole in the axle. It is a tight fit and may require printing a percent smaller if your printer has sub par tolerances. Glue together the short and long axle if you have printed them separately.

You will need to print:
(2) axle bolts
(2) axle nuts
(2) complete axles, either the short and long, or just the axle STL depending on if you want to use supports or not
(4) wheel nuts
(1) camera roller body
(1) 1-4 20 camera screw (use real hardware for this part if possible)

then attach your favorite tripod head and gt great shots!

I drew and printed up some legs for my Hubsans to get them further off the ground (both for prop clearance in higher grass and for ground clearance for my Runcam Split). If you want them longer or shorter, it's easy enough to change that size in your 3D Printer's slicer. I picked this particular size as it is the minimum size which allows ground clearance for my Runcam Split at any angle.

I've attached them with 2 small zip ties and then (because I'm persnickity), I UV welded them in two spots. If you tighten the zip ties well enough there is no problem, but... with the UV weld, they won't budge (with the added benefit that a quick snap of the wrist breaks that weld if you want to remove them). Everything total (legs and zip ties) weighs in at 14g and doesn't make much difference in flight time.

As always, I printed these with PETG. I went with 10% infill, and trust me, they are strong!

description.text:
sooo .. ich habe sehr oft gelesen, dass bei vielen die Steps vom Extruder nicht stimmen und deswegen habe ich mal eine Filamentlehre zum berechnen der Steps konstruiert.... sie ist für Filament von 1.75 - 3 mm Filamentdicke geeignet.

Formel 100 / angezeigte Wert x " Wert, der in Marlin steht * und dann dieses Ergebniss eingetragen und wieder flashen....

Also.... wer keinen Messchieber hat, kann diese Lehre nehmen und dann damit seine Steps einstellen.

Anleitung: Nozzel auf 200 Grad vorheizen, PTFE von der Druckdüse aus der Kupplung entfernen, Filament direkt am Schlauchende abschneiden und den Schlauch ( PTFE ) direkt in die Lehre einschieben. Im Slicer 100 mm extruieren und dann nachmessen was wirklich herausgekommen ist. Die Lehre ist in in 1 und 5 mm Schritten unterteilt.

Berechnung : 100 / angezeigte Millimeter * Wert der in Marlin steht ( M92 ) und diesen Wert stattdessen eintragen und neu flashen
.

description.text:
Hugo Toy Car

v 1.0.0

Mechanics

Linear bearing LMU88 x2

Printed Parts

Wheels

Axis x2
Wheel Hook x2
Tire x4
Rim x4

Spotlight

Frontal White Spotlight x1
Back White Spotlight x1
Back Red Spotlight x1

Bodywork

Car Roof x1
Trunk x1
Lateral left x1
Lateral right x1
Front doors x1
Back doors x1
Frontal x1
Exausht Pipe x1
Bumper x1

Inside

Inside x1

Decorations

Roof x1
Grill x1
Lateral Embelliser Left x1
Lateral Embelliser Right x1
Back hook x1

Luggage

Luggage x1
Luggage1 x1
Luggage2 x1
Luggage3 x1

Assembly

For joining the pieces I recommend using PVC glue, silicone or any strong glue. The doors in this first version can not be opened!

  1. Glue the Lateral Embellisers to the doors and car laterals.

  2. Join the bodywork pieces except the lateral bumpers and glue the roof, the back hook, the spotlights, and the grill.

  3. Apply a layer of varnish to make the structure strong, and let it dry off, meanwhile, glue the linear bearings into the wheel hooks and glue it to the inside.

  4. Join the inside with to the bodywork and apply another layer of varnish.

  5. Glue the tire into the rim and all this piece to the axis (just one extreme), insert into the linear bearing and glue the other wheel.

Recommendations

Be patience at the assembly.
Sand the pieces before glue it to improve adhesion
If there is something wrong with the pieces I ll try to fix it as soon as you tell me.

More vehicles coming soon.

title: Tony Stark Arc Reactor Adjustable 1Watt LEDs & Power Base

description.text:
Wanted to make one of these for my Desk at work but wanted it to do a little more than just light up. Tested with some blue LEDs and found out needed a bit more to look right. Used 1Watt Blue High Power LEDs. With the higher current had to add transistors and since each light needs to be controlled separately I ended up with 11 different LED channels. Controlled by an Arduino Nano. I needed a place for all of the electronics to hide and after re-watching the first Iron Man Movie noticed they used an adjustable power source to first light the Arc reactor Mr. Strak built in the cave. Thought it would be cool to model that in Fusion 360 and use it to contain all of my electronics.

Check out Video that shows the adjustable spin effect on the LEDs.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=enZw0Q6WSoI

Really neat project and printed really well on my Duplicator I3.

description.text:
This fits over the top of a standard J-Nozzle and extends it by 1 inch.  
I sized it slightly longer, allowing me to trim the top edge down to fit my needs precisely.  
I used it to swap an original Eventorbot hotend out for a MKV clone.  The extra length was required to fit in the same bracket.  
Update: I rebuilt the design in OpenSCAD (rev 03), so that the extension height and the diameter of the filament hole could be adjusted.

Adjust the OpenSCAD file to suit your needs.  "Extension" controls how much it will physically extend the tube, and "filament_diameter" controls how big the actual filament hole will be.  
Print with a fairly high temperature to help the layers fuse together strongly.  
You will have to drill the very end of the filament tube--I closed it off so that it would print more gracefully.  
For best results, I recommend ABS with an acetone vapor bath to fuse the outer shell together even better.  
Tap the top hole with M10 x 1.0 and threading should be the same as the top of the J-Nozzle.

Follow me on Instagram: @guaro3D

This model have been develop from pictures of the beautiful Cafe Racer 1979 SR500 belonging to Hannover-based Patrick Frey industrial designer, so the beautiful form is his creation, I just translated to a 3d printable model and made some small changes for simplification and easier print process.

The model is at 1/16 scale and have been designed to be printed with a 0.4 nozzle, if you want you can scale it up or down for other scales, but of course for smaller scale you probably will need a 0.3 or 0.2 nozzle to get nice results.

Please follow me on instagram to see the progress of other models and more pictures of the design process.

Any tip will be much appreciated to continue the develop of more free models,or you can purchase the others models on cults3d.com. link:

https://cults3d.com/es/usuarios/guaro3d/creaci%C3%B3n

Greetings, happy printing

title: Cute Pudgy Owl Fridge Magnet - Remixed from BudgiesAreCool's model.

description.text:
I really like the original model, and wanted to give a bunch out to some people - but I don't like giving out "Statue" prints, as I like for gifts to have some use to them besides just being absolutely adorable.
So I cut off the back of this model and shoved a 1 inch diameter hole in the back for a magnet.

I was able to get this to print with no supports, but the woodfill seems to be really good at bridging so I'm not sure I'd have had the same success with my normal PLA.
I never spent too much time tweaking my bridging settings, so use your best judgment on whether or not you need supports :)

I purchased these magnets and used their measurements to determine the hole size, but any 1 inch diameter magnet should be fine:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01BX1MC6Y/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Filament Guide for Anet A8 Frame

description.text:
I'm not 100% happy with this design yet. It's small and sometimes isn't that good at doing it's job.

I made this one now that I like more. It's bigger but works better

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551356

This is a simple and very small filament guide for your Anet A8 (or other printers with frames around 7.50mm to 7.75mm)

Understanding the file names.

1.75 (Is the filament size what will go thru the gap they have)

7.50 and 7.75 (Is the gap between the "arms")

Side and Top is where they have the gap for the filament.

Been such an small and fast print, I suggest you print the 4 of them and see what works best for you.

Please if you print them photos and feedback is always welcome.

title: Dragon Keychains (I'll model from your designs!)

description.text:
Post a comment with a link to an image and I'll make a 3D model keychain of it!

I wanted to make some cool-looking keychains, and I found a pretty good process to do that! So good, in fact, that I'll model up a design that you send me and add it to this post! Please try to use creative commons images or your own line-art, and it needs to be a fairly simple black and white design in order to work well. That's really it for now, so have some dragons!

These were all printed with a 0.2mm nozzle, and the circle dragon was printed at 115% scale. Feel free to scale these up, as they should still fit on most key rings even at 200%.

title: Turntable for Airbrush, Painting, Modeling Photos Rotating, 608 or BB bearing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 8/4/2017: Updated Top BB bearing and added new 608 bearing versions for Top and Base. The BB raceway tends to require some post-processing for silky smooth operation. 608 bearing versions are fully interchangable with other section types. Top is further inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2035825 with integrated hooks along the edge.

A turntable that can be expanded as needed. 6mm Airsoft BB's (up to 42) are used as ball bearings for free rotation. 4.5mm BB's can also be used but aren't as good. I used a 20mm M3.5 bolt with washer and nut with a bit of loctight to secure the top and base so the bearings don't fall out. Turntable diameters are Top: 108 mm (4.25") and Top Extended: 177 mm (7")

Mix and match pieces as you need but only Top and Base are required. I used crossed toothpicks or Cups in Height Extension and Feet sections to add ballast (lead buckshot in small baggies) for a more stable turntable but ballast isn't required with just one Height Extension and Feet section. The threaded cup can also be used for securing to a platform if you don't want to just drill holes for screws.

Lots of various diameter, location and orientation holes for plugs, toothpics,wires, rods, ect.

Additional tools used in painting: toothpics, rubberbands, pieces of wire for elevation of model, handling and securing pieces for painting, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1669403 , https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2117261

To Do: insert-able domed plugs, angled toothpick plugs, pcb clamp-like wing/thumb screw/ adjustable clamps, articulated arms https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279 , toothpick crane arms https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2111631, redesign for threaded section connecting, improve Top 608 bearing stability (wide base structure/ roller wheels/ )

title: Hinge- and Grip set for Ultimaker 3 DIY front door

description.text:
Although the Ultimaker 3 (extended) is an almost complete 3D printing machine, a front door is missing. Ultimaker themselves recommend a front door especially for higher tempertature prints (e.g. ABS). A fornt door improves the temperature stabilization inside the machine for better printing results.
The proposed set of things comprises all items to install such a front door. I adapted a transparent 4 mm acrylic plate to the printer's cutout. The hinge parts on the door side as well as the grip handle must be fixed to the plate by use of M3 screws and nuts. The both frame-side hinge parts should be fixed to the printer's front plate with small countersunk drywall bolts e.g. 2.5 mm x 10 mm.

title: Game of Thrones Dragon Egg Tea Cup
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A Game-of-Thrones-inspired tea cup that looks like a dragon's egg. Holds about 6 fluid ounces of liquid (177 ml) when printed with coordinates in mm.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Resolution:

0.5mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Prototyped in PLA on the TAZ 5, using Lulzbot Cura for slicing. Ultimately intended for production in porcelain by Shapeways.

I started with mrtom82's Game of Thrones Dragon Egg Container, then I rounded the top edge and added a handle based on energywave's Tea Cup Holder.

All editing was done by importing the original STL into OpenSCAD and manipulating them there.

Each of the three pieces (the original egg, the rounded lip on top, and the stretched handle) must be exported individually as STL, then merged in Meshlab using "Flatten Visible Layers". (OpenSCAD's union() failed to produce a 2-manifold output.)

Attempts to export the entire design as one STL file and fix up in either Meshlab or Netfabb all ended in utter disaster. Either the faces were all screwed up, or solid slices were added to the middle by Cura, etc. Exporting in three pieces and merging in Meshlab was the only viable solution I found.

Finally, I rotated the model -90 degrees on the Z axis to produce a better Thingiverse thumbnail.

description.text:
Update 19.08.2017 evening ;-) : changed the files to v2 with added hexmounts for the ac socket and the jam sockets on the front for easy mounting!

Update 19.08.2017: Good news: the printed parts are OK. Though I did some small corrections in the design. Now the thing is ready for printing. So you can start your printer ;-))

Update 18.08.2017: Iam just printing the finished design v1

Update 14.08.2017: i have optimized the airflow system ;-) Printed the top part successfully. After 12h of printing the bottom part i had an electric failure in the house.... will restart the print soon!

Would be great if you could share your makes!!

Inspired from this thing : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2336137
I created a cheap Lab PSU for supplying 1-30VDC form a 230V source.
The parts are under construction and will be ready for printing soon.
Iam waiting for the DC step up/down to arrive then i will see what poti you will need to buy.

I have done 2 Versions of the bottom part.
Nr. 1 is with fanswitch on the back
Nr. 2 is without fanswitch on the back

For the fan protection you may use this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1655833

Here is your shopping list:
4mm banana socket. any socket with 12mm shaft will fit.

The second option to connect wires is: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2017-New-Hot-5-Pcs-2-Positions-Connector-Terminal-Push-in-Jack-Spring-Load-Audio-Speaker/32802688094.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.ybhKBu

The display: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/DC-0-30V-10A-Voltmeter-Ammeter-Blue-Red-LED-Panel-Amp-Digital-Volt-Gauge-meter/32597785507.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.ybhKBu

The on/off switch: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Baomain-IEC-320-C14-Red-Light-Rocker-Inlet-Male-Power-Supply-Connector-Plug/32706948395.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.1YhDuu

The AC/DC converter: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/AC-85-265V-to-DC-12V-8A-AC-DC-50-60Hz-Switching-Power-Supply-Module-Board/32757672580.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.1YhDuu

The DC step up/down converter: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/LTC3780-DC-5-32V-to-1V-30V-10A-Automatic-Step-Up-Down-Regulator-Charging-Module/32709008474.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.uQhyV3

Optional switch for the fan ( i will make two versions of the case): https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2-Pieces-Lot-New-Green-Mini-2-pin-Round-Toggle-Selflocking-Power-ON-OFF-Push-Button/32799681095.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.uQhyV3

The 12V fan: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1Pcs-Black-2-Pin-12V-40mm-x-10mm-4010-Brushless-DC-Fan-PC-Cooling-Cooler-Fan/32632874913.html

The Potis:
for the current control: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/WH148-B200K-15mm-3Pin-0-5W-200K-OHM-Linear-Taper-Rotary-Carbon-Potentiometer-Pot/2046505046.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.ONxA74

for the voltage control: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10-PCS-High-Quality-WH148-B500K-Linear-Potentiometer-15mm-Shaft-With-Nuts-And-Washers-500K-OHM/32227585423.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.ONxA74

Printer:

Samella v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

i used 2 perimeters und 2 top and 2 bottom layer.
I used support for the ac-plug and the display section but as i noticed its not neccessary.
i printed it with a speed of 50mm/sec.

title: Apple 2e disk II to Mini Mac Case conversion kit parts

description.text:
Parts enable conversion of a disk II 5-1/4" external floppy drive to hold an Intel Mini mac and have the drive work through the slot etc

macfrontlift – This is a small strip of a very particular size to sit under the black front facia which used to be held by the drive internals. – I did 100% fill

macfrontdriveflsp – The slots push fit into the back of the drive flap (pictured) to stop it falling out of its hinge. It again it normally attached to the drive innards. I did 50% fill

macfrontboardmount – This again is a very specific size to hold the mini mac on and above the base so the CD drive slot matches with the floppy slot. I attached the motherboard to this with silicone. – Printed 40% fill

macfrontrear – Optional as you will have to cut off the rear aluminium plate to use it. Allows the cable to go through and fan to vent, with a cutout for a cheap ebay push to make switch for power. Printed with 25% fill.

The mac mini LED wire can be spliced to the “in use” red LED infront of the drive and will work !
The Power switch wires in to the rear switch for power and reset. It’s then self-contained.

PLEASE DON’T DO THIS WITH WORKING OLD DRIVES ! I obtained this one broken and infact rusty inside from a garden shed !

print_settings.Notes:: A raft is really recommended for the pin. For the other parts it is optional.

description.text: Here's a small box to keep your picks in. The top of the box swivels around on a plastic pin and snaps into place. There is a small hole in the top at the back for running a cord through if desired. See assembly notes below.

Printer:

Anet A8 Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 mm height

Infill:

at least 10%

Notes:

A raft is really recommended for the pin. For the other parts it is optional.

Step 1: Print out the pick locket bottom, pick locket top and either the fat or skinny pin. Actually both pins are very close in size, but I've found that some of my filaments print out slightly larger or smaller, so it might be worth it to print both and use the one that fits best. Also, a raft is recommended for the pins. Position the top on the bottom so that the divots in the top and bottom line up in the locations shown. Insert Pin through the hole in the top. The fit should be snug enough that pliers or a light tap from a hammer are needed to get the pin to seat all the way. Otherwise it's liable to back out with repeated use.

print_settings.Notes:: Print it in ABS if possible for maximum heat resistance.

title: Desk Cable Ports for 3"(64mm) holes (Ikea SIGNUM replacement)

description.text:
I didn't like the gray cable ports that I got with my Ikea desk so designed these replacements. The main reason I wanted something different was the color but my design has a couple advantages over the original Ikea part. They are easier to use because you don't have to pass the cables through them. Just arrange the cables into the slots and push into place. They also fit more snug than the Ikea parts. I made a blank, 1 port and 4 port versions because that's what I needed right now but I think I will also make 2 and 3 port versions.

If you don't already have the installation kit from Ikea you need a 3" hole saw to cut the hole in the desk.

I printed with 20% infill, 3 shells, 3 top and bottom layers.

description.text:
It is a simple wind direction indicator. Look at it and see which way the wind is blowing. It gives an indication of the wind speed, see how fast it is spinning. And the 24/7 bit?? No problem seeing it at night, I printed it in 'glow-in-the-dark' filament!!

EDIT..!! After a couple of months it seemed like this would last forever but...

We had some extreme winds last night and the tail snapped off.
So I have made a thicker one that is a lot stronger. Try the 'tail44' file if you are in a very turbulent location

title: Nerf Stryfe (UltraStryfe) Brushless Motor Cage & Wheels
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Built for the stryfe and RaceStar 3000KV 2205 Brushless motors ONLY ..For more info sit back and relax while you watch the videos :)

Website
Http://Ultrasonic2.com

Facebook Group
https://www.facebook.com/groups/115961665148248/

Worker on AliExpress
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/NNNF6Qj

Nerf Ammo on AliExpress
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/66yZ3fu

Worker on Amazon
http://amzn.to/2FK7xfG

Nerf Ammo on Amazon
http://amzn.to/2BUpPIQ

Nerf Blasters on Amazon
http://amzn.to/2FIgRk6

FYI you do not need to cut the stryfe to fit the motors in so NO "Motor cover" is required.. Mine has motor covers because previously i was running 180's. This means your blaster can look completely stock if you wish. HOWEVER Since "Gen 2" the end of the Flywheel motor bolts will grind against the inside of the Shell. You can drill the Shell this and cover the holes OR Grind 2mm off the top of the Bolts and thus it wont grind on the Shell. (Watch Gen 2 Video)

Printed on Tronxy X3A 3D Printer

The Licnence you agree to when downloading this thing prevents you from making a profit from MY thing. This means you CAN NOT sell this or any of my other things on places like Ebay, Facebook, Forums or Etsy. You also may Not sell My parts as Part of a complete blaster. I don't profit from putting this thing us as a Free download and therefore no one else should too.

Due to the specific print requirements required to print a successful Ultra cage and Wheels we have now opened a Etsy store. Purchasing from this store you can be assured a HIGH quality product .. Not some cheap disappointing rubbish.
Also a complete drop in kits including the cage and wheels are also available to those who are looking for a simple drop in kit.
https://www.etsy.com/listing/571034709/ultrastryfe-brushless-motor-cage-by
Another option is this APPROVED user.
https://www.ebay.com/sch/preylude3/m.html?_trksid=p3692

Please consider Leaving me a TIP for this Free Nerf Mod ...Thanks

THING FILES

Ultrasonic2 Stryfe Cage Gen x.x.STL
3D Printed Stryfe motor cage (Does not Fit Rapidstrike)

Wheels
Wheels are now maintained at this link.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2585080

Ultra-Nerf-NO-Brake.ino
Arduino Code
There are 2 options
Brake time setting
FallToTime = 0 for no brake ESC, 4000ms or greater for Braked ESC's
Accelerate time setting
RiseToTime = 0ms for 3s batteries .. 4s 50 to 1000ms MAYBE required.
Optional Trimpot to adjust RPM
int EnablePot =0 ; // 1 = yes 0 = no
int InveretPotDirection = 0; // 1 = yes 0 =no

NO Brake BLHeli_Noname - EMAX_Ltng_20A - Rev. 14.9 - Multi_171206.ini
BLheli Flash code for EMAX lightning 30amp ESC

Ultra-Nerf.ino (Not recomended)
Arduino Code Brake
Used for people buying BlHeli_S or BlHeli_32 ESC where you can't turn the brake off. The Arduino code slowly reduces the RPM AFTER the trigger pull to reduce the braking effect ... The braking effect causes extreme heating. Even with this code 4s operation results in extreme heating of the cage leading to melting.

Parts List
Arduino Nano 3.0 With CABLE & Pre-Soldered Pins
AliExpress http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/Eu7QRnm
Amazon http://amzn.to/2FZJCJy

Rectifier Diode
Aliexpress http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/MFeUrJ2
Amazon http://amzn.to/2FVT2G5

28V To 5V FIXED Buck
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/eQ7aEee
Amazon http://amzn.to/2u7P0Jo

RaceStar 3000KV Brushless Motors (3000KV RECOMENDED)
Aliexpress http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/uJ2vnEy
You need one Clockwise Motor and One Counter Clockwise. Use thread lock on the M3 bolts, otherwise they may come loose.
Amazon http://amzn.to/2pvluZd

EMAX BLHeli lightning 30A ESC
Aliexpress http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/fQBiaYv
Two ESC's are required.

ESC BLHeli USB Programmer
Aliexpress http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/3RRby3B
Amazon http://amzn.to/2pxozY7

ESC signal Y extension
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/mmqBqVN
Must be twisted. Straight wires can lead to glitchy operation.(Seriously)

2x 3M 18 Gauge AWG Silicone Rubber Wire Cable
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/feqJE6i
For extending ESC input power (one cable per ESC)

20 AWG Flexible Silicone Wire Cable 20AWG
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/vJEqjEq
(Used between the ESC's to Motors)

28AWG Flexible Silicone Wire Cable
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/aEQrrNb
Used for connecting everything other than the the motors' / ESC's

10k Pot
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/vbYFEYZ
This is OPTIONAL (can be used to adjust the max RPM/FPS)

ESC Servo Tester (This will require 5v input voltage.)
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/6qrRZbE
This is OPTIONAL (Not actually Required for the mod But useful for testing)

DO NOT power these motors with low cost low frequency ESC's. ONLY power them with high frequency ESC with F396 CPUs @ 48mhz. Otherwise the ESC's will be unable to spin the HIGH pole count motors at the expected speed of 37800 and results will be poorer.
Also ensure the firmware on the ESC is update (very simple to do with the BLHelli app) As improvements in topend rotations have been made ( FYI mine were 3 revisions behind out of the box).

Suggested battery
ZOP Power Lipo Battery 11.1V 2200Mah 3S 30C
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/3NNb6UN

Suggested Charger
Lipo Balance Charger iMAX B6 charger + 12v 5A Power Adapter + Charging Cables
http://s.click.aliexpress.com/e/NjE2R7E

Update 27/Oct/2017
Change ESC flash code to prevent it from resting its self up Please ensure you've updated your ESC to this.

Update 28/Oct/2017
Gen 2.0 Cage And wheels are released. This is a COMPETE redesign from the ground up

Update 31/Oct/2017
Gen 2.1 reduced the OD of the barrel

Update 4/Nov/2017
ESC Code .. Reduced acceleration due to d-sync issues, Particularly bad with super high quality batteries.
Gen 2.2 Improved entry to the barrel

Update 4/Nov/2017
ESC Code .. Reduced acceleration due to d-sync issues, Particularly bad with super high quality batteries.
Gen 2.2 Improved entry to the barrel

Update 16/Nov/2017
Reverted most of the change made in ..."Gen 2.1 reduced the OD of the barrel" It is still smaller that G2.0 though....

Update 1/Dec/2017
Gen 2.5 Removed short barrel to allow of larger ID though the cage.

Update 4/Dec/2017
Added code to support A trimpot to allow the adjustment of MAX RPM/FPS

Update 6/Dec/2017
Updated wiring diagram to reduce interference.
Re-added No brake code and ESC Flash for 4s operation. (To keep it cooler)

Update 10/Feb/2018
Updated wiring diagram. Changed buck to 5V and wiring.

85

Notes:

title: Safety Pin to Badge Back thingy

description.text:
So this might already exist in droves on Thingiverse, but I wasn't able to find one. That said, not completely sure what it's called, so my search terms were probably just bad.

This is just a simple little thing to make safety pins stand up straight on the back of a printed badge, so you don't need to go buy actual pin-backs or whatever the darn things are called.

The safety pins I used are about 3.3cm long, but I think the model should be re-sizable on the long axis without causing issues.

I've been using hot glue to affix them so far which hasn't had any problems, but super glue may also work fine.

I may modify it slightly to increase the width and depth of the channel in the bottom bit to better hold onto the Safety Pin's bar at some point, but probably only if I ever find it to be a problem.

Edit: Updated this with 4 new variations of the size, as well as added a picture with a ROUGH sizing chart. Hopefully these will give a bit more flexibility with the variances in safety pin sizes.

title: Floor vent guard for stupid robot vacuums

description.text:
This is probably something I will be the only one to ever use, but eh.

We have a couple of robot vacuums. The heavy hitter is the Neato Botvac connected, but as good as it is it kind of sucks at edge cleaning. That's where the cheapo Chinese knockoff comes in - the Ecovacs Robotics Deebots. There's other 'brands' out there they look almost identical. Unfortunately they're also dumb as a sack of hammers... but they do edging really well due to the big swirling brushes they use to funnel debris in towards the main brush.

Problem is the drop sensors are stupid sensitive and our little guy loves to pick a fight with one of the AC floor vents in one bathroom. It's the old style run of the mill metal vent that has not changed as far back as I can remember as kid in the 70s. Without fail the poor little Deebot gets immediately stuck on the vent due to the rudimentary drop sensor (An simple IR LED/beam and a receiver) and it gets 'stuck' between the metal slats. It hardly tries to free itself before just going catatonic and calling for help.

SO I whipped this up in Tinkercad to guard the front of this particular air vent. It's not fancy, and could use some improvements, but it works well enough.

Things it could use - A way to hook over the vent itself. It's not very secure, especially on tile, so I used some spray adhesive to attach it to the vent and that keeps it still. If used on carpet it could use some teeth on the bottom to help it stay in place. It could use some bracing as well, but it works. It's in two parts due to the size, with a little bridge piece that allows for some adjustment for longer vents.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kAwUR6SX5Ds

print_settings.Notes:: I printed in black PETG, at 30% infill the design uses about 25m of 1.75mm filament.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I am a geocacher and I often do bicycle trips. For my old Samsung S3 mini I had a bicycle holder which was a water tight pouch which could be attached to the handle bar.

Now I have an Ulefone Armor, an IP68 smartphone. It is significantly larger than my old phone so that I could not use the old holder. I found a similar pouch at the Swedish store Biltema - but the thick plastic window made operation difficult, and why put an IP68 smartphone into an IP67 pouch?

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed in black PETG, at 30% infill the design uses about 25m of 1.75mm filament.

Re-using the commercial handlebar mount

The handlebar mount from the Biltema holder is robust and has some amount of shock-absorption built-in. I originally also liked the design of the removable mechanism on the backside of the pouch, which would lock the pouch in place.

The mounting point itself is a 30mm x 30mm plate, 2mm thick on a narrower stem.

I then started with construction of the tray which should hold the smartphone in place. I thought of different locking mechanisms, partly inspired by other Things. However, I realized that I could arrest the phone very stable if I gave it a full support on the bottom part, not covering the pushbuttons and a locking rubber band for support at the top.

The phone itself rests with its back in a recess, which gives additional stability.

For the locking mechanism, I partly rebuilt the original mechanism with a plastic spring, but instead of a moveable plastic part I am using the solid back of the phone to lock the attachment piece firmly in its place as long as the phone is mounted.

The protruding anchor points for the rubber band and for the attachment of the lower part of the phone should also give the phone additional protection in case something fails. I have tested the holder on slightly bumpy roads - and so far I am very confident with this design.

It should not be a big problem to design a handlebar anchor for this holder, but I will continue to use the one which I already have.

Since I attach the (fully) parametric OpenSCAD files it should also be possible to adapt the tray to any other smartphone. However, if you don't have an IP68-class phone you should remember that you don't have any protection against rain.

A complete braille alphabet from A to Z. Use these files in your own designs to create tactile tools for education, fun, or both!
NGSS CCSS

This is complete braille alphabet database containing files of every letter A-Z. These files contain tactile dots for each individual letter in the alphabet. This compilation of braille letters is not for direct printing. Instead, they are provided for others to incorporate them in their own designs. This way, people can save time on making each individual dot, and have the entire braille alphabet ready to be used in their latest tactile creations. The uses of braille in 3D printing is providing endless possibilities for the future of visual impairment. From creating fun games, reading materials, educational tools, and gadgets for day to day life, 3D printing is making new ways see and feel the world. Dimensions: -Each dot is a semi sphere with a radius of 0.635 millimeters.
-The spacing of dots within a letter is 2.54 millimeters (0.1 inches)
-In the spacing of letters within a word, there is a distance of 5.08 millimeters (0.2 inches) between the centers of the last dot of the first letter and the first dot of the second letter. Braille Printing Tips: When 3D printing braille, it is best to do it vertically opposed to horizontally. When a printer forms dots on a flat surface, the extruder tends to just plop the plastic in the places of the dots. Thus, the dots come out ugly and rough. When braille is printed vertically however, the dots are made in better layers. As a result, they form better looking and smoother dots. Watch how to use these files to make words!

These braille dots can be incorporated into many designs to create reading materials, science diagrams, fun games, and tools to aid in the day to day life for visually impaired people. The possibilities of 3D printing braille is endless!

This is designed to mount to a wall or the side of the shelf. With 2 of these spaced apart, there is space for 3 file folders. The holes are Approx. 8 mm diameter (1/4"), and the top 2 are spaced at 25 mm (approx. 1"). I've also added holes on the prongs to make it easer to screw into a wall.

This was designed using Design Spark Mechanical, and so I've uploaded the RSDoc file as well, for easier re-mixing (eg - change angle to hold thicker files, change spacing of holes, add a 4th file holder, etc - whatever will work)

Printed with Anet A8 - may require some rotation to fit, depending on bed size.
No supports required, and minimal infill should be fine.

each piece when mounted measures approx. 226 mm high, and approx. 73 mm from the wall to the furthest support.

Currently, I have 4 pieces mounted to the side of a metal shelf on my desk at work, which allows me to hold 6 folders, and i've found it to be extremely convenient.

Enjoy!

title: Simple Shrinky Dinks Display Stand (Parametric)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This simple display stand was modeled after one included with a box of Shrinky Dinks toys that my kids got. ( http://www.shrinkydinks.com/ -- You should go out and buy lots of these, because they're loads of fun and the kids will have a blast!) The default size will fit a standard shrunken Shrinky Dinks piece. It's parametric, though, so you can change the size to fit other stuff as well. UPDATE: These are pretty popular with my kids, so I've added an STL with eight.

1) Print. 2) Insert Shrinky Dinks piece (or whatever else you want to put in it). 3) Chances are your kid now thinks you're the coolest dad/mom on the planet, so enjoy it while it lasts! There are three versions of the STLs: One has a single stand, one has four of the same (...x4.stl), and one was eight of the same (...x8.stl). If you want to adjust the size, you can use the OpenSCAD file. The following parameters are available:
  • baseThickness: The thickness of the base
  • baseWidth: The width of the base oval
  • baseLength: The length of the base oval
  • tabThickness: The thickness of each vertical "tab"
  • tabRadius: The radius of the vertical tabs
  • tabSeparation: How far apart the tabs are
  • $fn: Quality of circles

remixed_from.title: Vibration Damper for Flashforge Creator Pro 2016

title: Vibration damper for FlashForge Creator Pro (round feet)

description.text:
In typical Chinese fashion, FlashForge Creator Pro 2016 models seem to be shipped with small variations, for instance some are shipped with little round feet instead of the elongated feet on my model. User Shftatsix notified me of the update to helste's model to fit the round feet, and suggested a similar update of my original shock absorbers. I refined the proposed model and made a variation with a centered hole.

Like the original, these supports will only have a shock-absorbing effect when printed in a flexible filament like NinjaFlex, TPU, or similar. (You can print them in a rigid filament if you only need something to raise your printer 20mm from the floor without a vibration dampening effect.) For maximum effect, print with the lowest possible infill and number of perimeters that just don't cause the blocks to buckle under the weight of the printer.

print_settings.Notes:: 5 outside layers.

description.text:
E3D Titan Aero Extruder/Hot End mount for the Creality CR-10 printer.

This moves the print head nozzle about 15mm to the front of the printer. The vertical frame would need to be relocated to the rear so the whole bed can be utilized.

I just finished installing the mount and calibrated my extruder settings. Am using the E3D supplied stepper motor (0.9 degrees/step). Calibrated to 875 steps/mm on my printer.

Still need to modify the firmware to update the temperature probe setting to 5 (for Marlin), from the default value of 1, then start printing with it to see how it works.

The little bracket I made for where the extruder used to mount gives a place to secure the cables to the print head. Tap the hole for the PTFE tube fitting with 6mm thread. The hole opposite the fitting should fit a 4mm/6mm PTFE - just ordered some so to try.

Need four 3mm flat washers, two 3x10mm machine screws and two 3x6mm machine screws to secure the mount. Used two 3x10mm machine screws and nuts for the cable bracket.

Added CR-10AeroMount-r1.STL to work better with the slimmer E3D stepper motor (MT-1701HSM140AE) and allow the motor leads to go straight up. The prior version of the mount was modeled to work with the earlier version stepper motor I received from E3D (42BYGHM208P4.5-21-X2). The 1701 motor is about 60g lighter then the 42BYGHM208 and still offers 0.9 degree steps.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.5

Infill:

25%

Notes:

5 outside layers.

comments.text: Hi. I'm thinking, and this is purely theory... how about one fan to rule them all? Both for the nozzle heatsink as well as cooling the print. There are actually some designs out there for this .For instance my friend showed me his Cetus (see attached files). I'm thinking this would be good as the goal having a direct-drive setup would be minimal weight on the printhead. Wondering if anyone has an optimal Aero setup that incorporates parts-cooling which is still lightweight enough.

Hi

This is an attenmp to make a conversion of the imperial knight to a Space wolves knight.
Shane Blomberg (AKA ComradeQuiche) designed a superb space wolf and i wanted to make a similar conversion for my imperial knight

The hand is remixed and has some nice claws found on thingiverse
I used the back of the chainsword behind the glove (slice in 2 halves for print)
on each side of the head there are gatlings (taken from my gunship).

Please tell me if something is missing or hard to print, as i didn't print it yet.
edit 31/07/2017 : head is easy to print : flat side of the sphere on print bed, supports, wait 1hour.

cheers

description.text: First attempt to replicate a (roughly) 1:4 model of the TronXY X1 3d printer

Printer:

TronXY X1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

If the parts curl you can try to print it with a brim
The STL file contains both the assembled model and the part, so you need to remove the assembled model before printing.

Assembly requires 3 x M3 15mm screws to fix Z and X axises.
Alternatively you can use a piece of 1.75 filament as a plastic bolt.

Print the parts Assemble model

After printing the long thicker bar should be attached to the base plate with a plastic bolt or small screw
Likewise the X axis arm should be mounted on the vertical bar with 2 plastic bolts or small screws.

Design process

I used tinkercad.com online 3d modeling software.
Used basic shapes (solid and hole) to "cut" chunks out of the basic shapes.

• assembly
  • 3d printing
40 minutes
None

This is a tag for any event. You can either print out letters and glue it to the tag or just use a sharpie. The hole is big enough to fit a zip tie or string. Ever need a maze generated for OpenSCAD? If so, then this puppy is for you. It is a Python script which generates a random N x M maze and outputs a 3D description of it as an OpenSCAD program. The number of maze cells as well as the maze's physical size can all be controlled with command line arguments when running the Python script. The Python code can even be modified to generated non-rectangular mazes. (Hint: just throw up non-removable walls in the initialized maze data.) BTW, the Python code here is derived from the Eggbot Maze generator, Eggmazing, which is distributed with the Eggbot software and is an Inkscape extension. I wrote that extension for the Eggbot in the Fall of 2010 and want to again thank W. Craig Trader for the assistance he provided with that effort. Enjoy! 9 June 2012: Corrected invalid commenting style in line 1 of OpenSCAD output
9 June 2012: Added warning when wall thickness (-t) is explicitly set to be thicker than one-half the cell's width or length.

Download the maze.py Python script and run it, % python maze.py maze.scad where the last argument, maze.scad, is the name of the output file to generate. The output is an OpenSCAD program which you can then load into OpenSCAD and render. Use whatever file name suits your fancy. If no name is supplied, then the OpenSCAD program is written to standard output, stdout. The command line arguments can be seen with the command % python maze.py --help
Usage: maze.py [-cfhlrtw] [output-file]
-c, --columns
Number of maze columns running the maze width (default = 8)
-f, --floor
Physical thickness in millimeters of the maze floor (default = 2.000000)
-h, --height
Physical height in millimeters of the maze (default = 8.000000)
-l, --length
Physical length in millimeters of the maze (default = 30.000000)
-r, --rows
Number of maze rows running the maze height (default = 8)
-t, --thickness
Physical maze wall thickness in millimeters (default = 1.000000)
-w, --width
Physical width in millimeters of the maze (default = 30.000000)
output-file
Name of the output file to generated; if not specified then
output will be written to standard output The two attached .stl files, maze-8x8.stl and maze-10x10.stl, were both generated with this script.

comments.text: FWIW, there's now a warning when you select a wall thickness which exceeds one-half the cell's length or width.  I also changed the code to default the thickness to 0.2 times the smaller of the cell's length or width.
comments.author: laird

comments.text: -t does work, but possibly not as intuitively as it should. A wall thickness of -t10 (10 mm) is TOO thick. I wrote the code to make the -l and -w dimensions be the absolute length and width of the object. So, the dimension of each cell including its walls will be length/column-count by width/row-count. Using your 200 x 200 mm design with 16 x 16 cells, that makes for 12.5 x 12.5 mm wide cells. Now put walls which are 10 mm thick into that cell and you get a solid fill (since you have a 10mm wall on the left and a 10 mm wall on the right -- they end up overlapping).

remixed_from.author: dvjcodec
remixed_from.title: Cristelia - Open Source LCD SLA resin printer [ DayLight ]

description.text:
This project is complete as far as I am concerned

So, while I may have missed putting up some of the files, or something else. I am considering this project to be done. Unfortunately even though all my hardware worked very well, it was ultimately the hardware that did me in. Nano DLP is a tricky little thing to work with and made it neigh on impossible to proceed past the hardware and into printing. I would have loved to continue but I don't have the time or energy to rewrite nano dlp or figure it out. If anyone want's more instructions. Please just ask and I will be happy to help. Hopefully someone else can figure out the software.

This is my attempt to try and recreate the cristelia 3d printer, which unfortunately seems to have been abandoned. Things I have changed so far. The corners are now made to use 1in tubing that can be found easily in most american hardware stores. I have started to work on my own vat system in order to

Frame

8 x 12" aluminum tubing for top and bottom frames
4 x 17-20" tubing for sides (This is really dependent on how big you want the printer)

Parts

608-2RS Bearing
8mm lead screw with nut about 400mm.
Raspberry pi 3 with wifi (Or zero with wifi)
1 in outer diameter square tubing (8 feet or about 5 metres)
Ramps board
Arduino mega
12v power
Retina display for ipad 3 or 4
Nema 17 motor
Retina display driver (https://www.adafruit.com/product/1716 or https://www.amazon.com/HDMI-Controller-Board-LP097QX1-2048x1536/dp/B06Y426S7Z/ref=pd_sbs_147_1?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=ASK896JMF6GD9M9BRJ4E)

SD Card
Limit switch

Update 9/14/2017

Important things I have learned:
-DON'T CHEAP OUT ON THINGS
-Don't use a 12v laptop or led power supply, buy a bigger better one.
-Nanodlp does not work with a rpi zero
-Cheap chinese retina display to hdmi boards do not work, get the adafruit qualia instead
-Hdmi to display port is hard. Get an adapter that needs some sort of power supply.
-MDF does not a good printer base make
https://github.com/trinityalps/Kafka-DLP-Printer

Update 9/21/2017 Price breakdown

Aluminum tubing~40$
12V to 5V buck converter-2$
DC 12V 10A Power Supply-14$
HDMI to DisplayPort Converter Adapter with USB Power-40$
RETINA DISPLAY LP097QX1-SPC2-50$
2x12mm shaft 500mm long-15$
1/4 Inch aluminum, 12 x 12 inch sheet-24$
Limit Switch- 0.50$
Flexible Couplings 5mm to 8mm-4$
400mm 8mm Lead Screw-10$
R-PI 3-35$
2xLMK12LUU linear bearing-10$
Nema 17 stepper 13$
RAMPS 1.4 and Mega2560 R3-30$
A4988 Stepper Driver-2$
Qualia Board for LP097QX1-80$
FEP Film-10$
Misc Plastic, Screws, filament-10$

Total-359.50$

THINGS IN ITALICS YOU SHOULD NOT CHEAP OUT ON, BUY EXACTLY WHAT IS SAID

Cost Savings

Aluminum is the biggest area to save here. If you can find a cheaper source of aluminum go for it. The 1/4 plate I bought is far to big, you could easily get a 7*9 inch plate and it would work just fine. I cannot stress enough to just buy the qualia board, but you could try the abusemark board, but that still requires the active hdmi to display port with usb power. You can also save money if you can find a local shop that sells a retina display replacement, But be sure it's the right model. All in all you could maybe save 50~100$ depending on the parts you already own and your own creativity in sourcing parts. But I would recommend not cheaping out. Yes it can be under 300$ but sometimes just go for the good stuff.

Update 10/6/2017 Cheaper Alternatives

So the usb car charger exploded for some reason so instead I am switching a 12v to 5v buck converter, hopefully this won't explode. Due to difficulty controlling ramps with nano dlp, I am switching to the cheaper alternative of direct control with the pi through an A4988 stepper driver and attaching that direct to the rpi. It should work fine.

title: MPSM cable chain wider opening
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
** Updated base connector, see below

This is a remix for the Monoprice Bed rewire cable chain with modification of a wider opening to allow all the cables to thread through with out removal of the connectors.
It is assumed you have drilled a hole in the center of base of the MP Select Mini for threading the wires through.

The original design was such that the large connector for the heater rewiring would not fit through the chain link, the bed chain or the base chain.

The following changes have been made to the following:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2198351
"CHAIN_BED_V2.stl" has a wider hole to allow the threading of the wires. There are also two holes for a zip as can be seen in the 1st picture, and the 2nd picture with the wires (with heat shrink) and zip tied. The name of this new file is "CHAIN_BED_V2_dbmod.stl". Please note when mounting to the bed longer M3 screws might bed needed.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1167746
"CableChainLink.stl" has had a wider hole made for cable threading. Multiple links can be seen in the 3rd picture. Name of the new file is "CableChainLink_dbmod.stl"

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2151537
File "Chain_BASE_2.stl" has been widened with a circular opening with the new name "CHAIN_BASE_2_outside_dbmod.stl" (right part in 5th & 6th picture).
Also added is a cylindrical part called "CHAIN_BASE_2_inside_dbmod.stl" (left part in 5th & 6th picture) which is mounted in the inside of the hole. The fourth picture shows this arrangement with the cable going through the hole (note there is heat shrink tubing on the wires for protection). The "inside" part protrudes on the outside and press fitted into the "CHAIN_BASE_2_outside_dbmod.stl" part on the outside of the machine. There is a minor wedge shape to align the holes.
There are hole for twist ties but they did not work. Instead the tip of a twist tie goes between the wire and the inner part of "CHAIN_BASE_2_inside_dbmod.stl" as per picture 7. The rest of the zip tie is cut and the tension keeps everything set.

** Base connector has been updated. Now one piece under the name "cable_chain_base_new.stl" (12th photo - 3rd from last).
Supports will be needed for the overhang of the tube. I did supports only at 75 degrees.

Thread the cable through the connectors, cables through the back hole and then press the connector through the hole (all outside to in).

I have holes for the cable ties. On the inside (13th photo) one cable tie goes into two of the holes and tie around. Not much cable support but good for stopping the connector from being pulled through. On the outside (14th photo) I managed to thread the cable tie through the top holes and then back around the bottom, which hopefully holds the cables (most likely through tension). Please note I do have heat shrink on the cables.

  • Note1: I'm using cheap cable ties from a dollar store.
  • Note2: I added an extra link to my chain. 9 links is not enough and had too much tension.

description.text:
My first ever design.

Just a basic spool holder i threw together while drunk because i got annoyed by my printer having it's holder on the back (where i can't see it run out of filament).

This mount allows you to put the spool on top of the machine, making it much slimmer and allowing it to fit onto smaller desks.

This has been designed for a rod of 24mm, i just used the top of a broom handle.
Designing a 3d printed rod is left as an exercise for the reader.

Holes have been provided if you're the OCD type and want to align it with the holes on the machines. But the base clips on rather snugly, and can hold at least a kilo of filament (that's all I've tested with).

JGAURORA Z-603S

No

0.2

10%

Notes:

Supports will be needed if you're printing the whole thing in one shot.

Print 2 sides and the base, superglue is plenty strong to attach the sides (i used far too much in the example images, less is more in this case. Unless you wanna sand some away after).

Installation is super simple, first click the bottom of the holder onto the top left or right of the printer, and then click the top of the holder into place. Use any pole you want through your spool and place it onto the holder. I used the top of a broom handle, perfect size.

Supports will be needed if you print the whole thing in one shot.

I printed the fins upright (pin tabs hanging off the sides with and bracket mount thing on top) at 0.4mm & 0.2mm layer height and 75% infill (triangle & tetrahedral pattern). Then just trimmed/sanded the pin tabs so they would fit properly.

For the bracket - I did 100% infill @ 0.2mm layer height

Created in FreeCAD based on object measurements.

  • Fin doesn't have the nice curved profile that the stock fins have, but it gets the job done.

description.text: A simple holder for the LivewireTS tuning computer. I didn't like the bulky suction cup holder it came with.

My MP Select Mini scares the crap out of me whenever the spool jerks as something is getting printed. So when I read this reddit thread I got the idea to deisgn my own spool holder. I can't say whether it makes my prints any better or not but I thought it wouldn't hurt.

It uses two standard (?) ABEC bearings.

I printed it on PLA and the weight of the spool bends it down enough to cause it to bend and touch the base which keeps it from spinning freely. Because of tolerances I can pull the shell out enough to avoid this issue. I might update the design if this becomes too much of a hassle.

I had to print the shaft with supports and a brim. Because it's long and thin it started to wobble as it got taller which caused the print to fail multiple times.
Z Limit switch mount to allow the Makerbot Thing-O-Matic Z axis to self-teach the platform height.

Z Axis Limit Switch Instructions The Z axis limit switch mount allows you to have your Thing-O-Matic self-teach the Z axis HBP Heated Build Platform position. I rarely tweak the Z offsets on my builds with this update. Parts: Limit switch block (Plotted), 2 M2 x 25mm screws, 2 M2 x 12mm screws, 4 M2 Nuts, 1 Makerbot Limit switch assembly (Available from the Makerbot Store). Assembly: (Note, the build platform needs to be leveled before proceeding) Plot the limit switch block. Lay it on its largest flat side (4 hole surface down) Place the limit switch assembly on the thin flange with the limit switch trigger leaf extending below the edge nearest the 2 mounting screw holes. Fasten the limit switch assembly to the thin flange of the block via the 2 M2 x 12mm screws and nuts. Mounting the Limit Switch Block: The limit switch block mounts with the switch down in-line with the plotting nozzle as you look across the HBP surface. I found just touching the corner of the build platform at the X-Y home position works well. Lower the Z axis assembly to just clearing the HBP then Home the HBP (push it by hand). Place the limit switch block on the side of the Z axis assembly in between the nozzle interface PCBA and Z axis guide shafts (edge of the limit switch block ~25mm from the rear edge of the Z axis assembly, such that it triggers when slid vertically down to contact the corner f the HBP. Scribe/mark 2 holes in the center of the slots in the limit switch block. Drill two 2 mm dia holes and mount the block to the Z axis assembly with the remaining 2mm screws and nuts. Adjust the limit switch vertically to trigger before the nozzle contacts the HBP surface. Connect the new Z axis limit switch cable to the limit switch assembly and route down to connect to the Z axis home location on the mother board. Code Changes: Locate the Start Code in the ReplicatorGxx\machines\Thingomatic directory. Add the lines to the code described between the comment lines (HBP Z Limit Switch Start) and (HBP Z Limit Switch End) below: ( beginning of start.gcode )
(This file is for a MakerBot Thing-O-Matic)
( begin initialization commands )
(â€¦ initialization code is hereâ€¦) ( end initialization commands )
( begin homing )
G162 Z F4000 (home Z axis maximum)
(G92 Z10 (set Z to 0)
(G1 Z0 (move z down 10)
(G162 Z F150 (home Z axis maximum)
G161 X Y F2500 (home X & Y axis minimum)
M132 X Y Z A B (Recall stored home offsets for XYZAB axis) (HBP Z Limit Switch Start)
G1 Z10 (Move Z down to 10)
G161 Z F250 (Move Z down until switch contacts platform)
G92 Z0 (Set Z to 0)
(Edit the following line to â€œfine tuneâ€ the height of the nozzle after the limit switch is set close)
G1 Z0.4 (Move Z to tweak offset due to sensor location)
G92 Z0 (Reset Zero after the tweak)
G1 Z10 F1500 (Move Z up 10)
( Z is Ready )
(HBP Z Limit Switch End) ( end homing )
( begin pre-wipe commands ) (â€¦ more start code continues hereâ€¦) ( end of start.gcode ) Set-Up And Calibration: Run a small test part such as a 20mm x 20mm x 3mm thick plate. Adjust the line in G-Code â€œG1 Z0.4â€ above to set the correct offset of the nozzle to the platform. Note: You will get a warning message from the Replicator software that you are homing in the wrong direction (just answer â€œProceed Anywayâ€), and the build will start.

OpenSCAD version of Otto. This is a working in progress. The head does not have any holes or supports for the "brain". In the mean while, you can use the head from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2398231

Some improvements:

  2. Thinner wall (it's configurable). The default value (1.6mm) prints perfectly with 0.4mm nozzle.
  3. You may change the servo you want to use. The default is MG90S (the one with metal gears). Not tested yet with SG90.
  4. Much more precision and tight joints. If your printer is not very accurate, please change the leg_space and k values in otto.scad file.

description.text:
So there I was late one night, I couldn't sleep so I was watching Infomercials and got bored of them, so went over and was watching Chuck Hellebuyck's channel (CHEP) and he did this thing with a tray that screwed into the front of his workbench and I said "self" that's cool but it requires commitment (i.e. to screw it in) so I said self "there has to be a better way" and in reading down the comments a viewer wrote Chuck saying "Neodymium magnets would be cool" and Chuck said go for it, its on Tinkercad! Well what was Chuck going to say as he already screwed his in :-) right? However it hit me right there in the wee hours of the morning! As I was just grocery shopping with the wife the day before and I always get a 6 pack of Coke Zero and hang it on the side of the cart so why not hang the drawer caddy on the front of the drawer? Bingo, up I sprang out of bed and didn't call Jake from State Farm but logged into Thinkercad and went feverishly to work on the design of a drawer caddy and as Emeril Lagasse would say BAM! Here it is the Drawer Caddy, the ultimate in exo-drawer storage technology and you can have it in your home not tomorrow but with any 200mm x 200mm 3D print today! Yesthat's right TODAY! Wait it gets even better yet if you can believe it, just print it today and you can print a second one (or two) tomorrow for free (well the cost of the filament and such is yours of course but its better than paying extra shipping and handling right? the lawyers made me add that).

Wait! As a special added bonus because your significant other most likely won't let you put that 3D printed stuff in the kitchen. We have a solution for you as there are many finishing options available (at an additional charge of course) should again you (or significant other) not like the 3D printed look (which my wife doesn't) as you can use a stone spray paint such this (http://amzn.to/2ue7gyw) which my wife even approves of or a lighter textured version such as this (http://amzn.to/2uewehx) to cover those nasty layer lines. As YES, with this can magic they will think you spent a fortune on them but it will be our little secret (I won't tell if you don't :-)! So what are you waiting for Christmas (by the way these make great stocking suffers too!). So don't wait, stop reading this and start printing today as you don't want your neighbors (you know the Jones) to have one before you! Don't Delay, download now before they are all gone!

P.S. If you make one, please post a make here on Thingverse to show us your use of this new exo-drawer storage technology in action and who knows we might even pick you yes YOU for our next infomercial! (if we did infomercials). However since we don't, we made this video https://youtu.be/2r9tNFrbN7Q to share more about this handy, dandy little device which is going to take over the kitchens of the world soon! So do yourself a favor and watch it as the Jones are watching it right now and you want to keep with the Jones right?

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

description.text:
Hi All,
this is my attempt to build a cheap gimbal for Canon EOS M and similar cameras.
The project requires soldering skills.
The result is very smooooooth =)

Work in progress: adding Canon remote control

infill: 25%
support: yes
perimeters\top\bottom: 3
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/djyp9ArdRFA" ></iframe>

• BGC 3.1 or compatible control board + MPU6050 [$8]
  • 2x brushless gimbal motors. I used EMAX Brushless Motor GB2808 [$15 each]
  • 3s or 4s battery. 1Ah capacity would be enough. I used 3s Turnigy nano-tech 950mAh [$16]
  • (if needed) tiny heat sinks for motor drivers on the control board [$1]
  • 4x4cm fan. I used Noctua NF-A4x10 FLX [n/a]*
  • power switch [n/a]
  • (recommended) 2-axis analog joystick. I used PlayStation Portable joystick [$2]
  • (recommended) Bluetooth module, like HC-05 or HC-06 [n/a]
  • (optional) push button [n/a]
  • a bunch of M3 screws (almost all can be substituted with 1/8 inch) [n/a]
  • M4 screw+nut [n/a]
  • 608zz bearing (like in spinners) [n/a]
  • some wires, soldering skills [n/a]
  • usbASP/ arduino/ anything else to flash the new bootloader [n/a]
  • patience [priceless]
  • mirrorless camera. I have a used EOS M [$200]
    Total: approx $60

    [n/a] - means I had those parts from other projects

Part 0 - software

Follow the instructions from here to upload the software to your control board:
https://www.basecamelectronics.com/downloads/8bit/

Typical scenario would be to upload a tiny bootloader via ISP pins and then load the hex file.

Part 1 - chassis

This is how I call the part that holds the camera.

  • first attach the fixed part of motor using 4 M3 screws to the chassis-roll part (from the inside)
  • attach the chassis-pitch part inside, using M3 screws
  • use the M4 screw, M4 nut, bearing-shim part and the bearing to attach the parts from the second side
  • take the MPU6050 and place it inside the tine cradle in chassis-pitch part, the MPU should be fixed (otherwise the gimbal will get 'fake' vibrations)
    connect the MPU cable and push it thru the motor
  • attach the second motor (rotating part) to the middle of the chassis-roll part from the outside, using only 2 screws - it will be opened after
  • push the wires of MPU and the pitch motor thru the roll motor
assembled chassis Part 2 - body
  • attach the roll-mount part to the motor (fix it as hard as you can, use threadlock if you have)
  • screw 'case' part to it (for now you need to cut a circular hole in the 'case' part)
  • add electronics (after burning the hex file and connecting the Bluetooth dongle (optional)
  • connect all the wires (motors, MPU, battery, fan, joystick, button)
Part 3 - handles
  • add handles, I recommend to add joystick ('handle_with_hole' part) on the right side and a power switch on the left
  • add a cooling fan to the second part of the case
  • attach all the parts together, connect the battery
  • screw camera to the cradle and power ON. You can either configure the gimbal via usb port or with Bluetooth application.
Canon remote control

Canon IR control protocol is very simple - https://publiclab.org/notes/cfastie/02-28-2016/auto-eos-m
So, I've designed a board that you can order for $0.75 per 3pcs here: https://oshpark.com/shared_projects/HcuCqs8k
and soldered it to the main controller board. The code is TBD - to share
Now I can take a picture (long press) or start/stop a video from the gimbal.

remixed_from.title: FT Gremlin Femto F3 Mount with Camera

description.text:
After reading a great tip by 8Bit_koopa in the Flitetest Forums http://forum.flitetest.com/showthread.php?33056-Flitetest-DIY-Gremlins&p=351391&viewfull=1#post351391 I decided to modify my original Femto F3 Camera Mount to add the sweet HGLRC Micro WS2812B Buzzer/LED combo he found.

Amazon Link :https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072X9H3B2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

While I was at it, I split the mount into two pieces to allow for easier installations on finished Gremlins. Having the back piece separate, allows you to easily slide it under the flight controller. Finally, I opened up the areas under the flight controller to allow for the new LED/Buzzer wiring and also to remove some weight to counteract the addition of the angled mounts out back.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

As on my original, supports are required. Take care removing them from your print as it is lightweight and delicate.

Sadly, I haven't had time to calibrate my MK2S so I am not able to print this in place as it was designed. Instead, I printed as two separate pieces and it fit back together nicely once mounted to the Gremlin.

Printed as two seperate pieces

Again, please disregard all the strings, I haven't yet dialed in this new Hatchbox Black PLA. Once those are pulled off, it really is a nice print.

This was intended to be a "print in place" design so I've included the combined STL as well as separate files for the front and rear pieces.

Ready to fly

Having the Buzzer is a really life-saver! These things quickly vanish in even the shortest grass so it is nice to have a mode switch on my transmitter to toggle the buzzer on and off to help locate.

I also REALLY appreciate the automatic low battery warnings it gives you via Betaflight!
Fusion 360

description.text:
NEWEST UPDATE: 06 Aug 2017 - For all of you mamma-jammas that printed the forend parts of the rail system (like I did) and DON'T have the benefit of the extension shank that is now on the forward forend piece, I'm making a bolt on addition that will mimic it. Its pretty awesome and actually uses the flutes in the barrel to lock in the bolts that are in the piece. I'm getting an M5 x .8 drill and tap, and plan on using M5 x 25mm socket head screws (locked into place with super glue). KEEP IN MIND that the barrel will still have to be sanded, painted, sealed...DONE...(whatever that means to you) before you do this install because it will positively engage the barrel via the fluting and will be irreversible after gluing.

04 Aug 2017 - Zen Meteor rifle scope (hollow), scope mount pieces, and a fully assembled single piece solid scope.

First things first:

All credit for the IP of this work goes to Bungie and ActiVision; thank you for giving us this great game.

Next thing:

THIS IS NOT YOUR DAD'S MODEL TRAIN SET. I've re-meshed this thing from zilch; from sneezes, air pie, and trodden dreams. It WILL require hand fitment and a robust understanding of construction techniques.

With that out of the way, here it is Fam - Zen Meteor - essentially an anti-material rifle for the gunpowder hedonists in all of us. It is a true 1:1 scale of the weapon in Destiny, and as such imposes several challenges to the would-be builder. As you can see this is a work in progress - I still have to mesh out the scope, and then go through a build iteration and post best practices for assembly. Before I get these out, if you have any questions, please hit me up in PM's and we can rap there.

CHALLENGE #1: It's Big.
*** It's REALLY big. It is also somewhat slender over that length, so there are critical parts and part junctures that NEED a lot of strength. Handling, showing, transporting this thing to and from CONs, cosplay parties, etc, will test its structural integrity. I've tried to engineer some good joints into this thing, and have a little more work to do on some pieces to give the design as much engineering cajones as it can possibly have. Also, it will take a LOT of material to print. Lastly, you may notice that the individual pieces themselves are large, too. That is because I have a 300x300x400 build area to work from, and I intend to use the whole thing. I will NOT be re-slicing these things so it can be built on an 200x200x200 printer.

CHALLENGE #2: It's Long.
*** Building this thing for strength and handling comes at a cost, and that is time. The forend (minus the rails) took 76 hours to print. The receiver takes 100 (when you use the shells and infill that I believe is required. Even if you are more conservative on your shells and infill, I kept the pieces as large as I could to print the biggest assemblies I was able to (so the size alone will still make longer prints than you may be use to). This is primarily due to my leaning toward threaded steel rods through the receiver to join the barrel, forend, and receiver together. Doing this pretty much dictates that building it in halves is a no-go because a tensioned threaded fastener would burst the center seam apart (or it would be trying to). Ultimately, it is going to take so long to sand this thing, prime it, paint it, weather it...and attempt to get it screen accurate...I just accepted the longer print times for the extra robustness it would provide.

CHALLENGE #3: Asssembly.
*** The order in which you build this thing MATTERS, particularly when you get to the gas block, the forward and aft halves of the forend, the rails, barrel, and receiver. Since I'm still tweaking things I DON'T have a definite build strategy though I have some ideas. I'll post the 'tried and true' method when I finalize all stages of assembly, but one thing that is immediately apparent up front is that the rear barrel (the pretty one with all the fluting on it and the sweet taper) will need to be sanded, painted, sealed, weathered, DONE before you put the forend together over it! And before you put the forend together, at very least the insides of the forend will have to be finished So there is a definite order of operations that should be followed - I just haven't put anything down as gospel yet.

Ultimately, the size of this build alone make it pretty ambitious. Please give feedback with any problems you run into - I'll try to be responsive about making any changes that need to be made in the files. As an aside, I was considering not releasing this because I like having unique things and benefitting form my work, but the community of makers and the coolness that is 3D printing is why I put all this work out in the first place. So here it is - the thing that I cut my teeth on learning Fusion 360, and breaking in my 3D printer.

Printer:

Creality CR 10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

Varies

Notes:

My thoughts on this are that shells and infill are lowest out toward the muzzle end, and progressively get denser until you reach the receiver, where they start tapering back again into the buttstock assembly. Use your best judgement, but the max I hit was 8 shells and 60% infill for the receiver.

description.text:
Decided to revisit the router stand and make something with more polish and complexity. So if you have an overheating router, spare filament to burn and 12 hours, this stand is for you.

No finished pic yet, as it takes 12 HOURS to print!

This is a universal spool holder using skate bearings. It is a great style of spool holder for people how has an enclosure for their printer.
The design has been carefully made to fit perfectly between the parts and to be printed using a resolution of 0.35 with a 0.4 nozzle but anyway it will probably work using another resolution. I also recommend to print it using 3 layers on the perimeter to get strong columns.

You have to print the part 4 times and 4 skate bearings to be able to make 1 universal spool holder.

Watch it fit together: https://youtu.be/pJDJmUl4MLE

EDIT: I have added what I call "drag spring". It's to prevent the spool from spin too much when the extruder pulls the filament. It just adds a bit of resistance.

Watch how I put it in: https://youtu.be/-Y49ox4xa2E

Skate bearing measurements:
-Inside Diameter: 8.00mm
-Outside Diameter: 22.00mm
-Width: 7.00mm

If you have any other improvement possible, please let me know.

print_settings.Notes:: hull down

title: AnimAlarm - a sensor to control pet movements

description.text: A simple but elegant project to create a "pet zone alarm" in your house. It uses infrared motion detectors to sense when a pet (or small child) is moving through a doorway or hall and sends out a loud tone. It does not beep when a (tall) person moves through the same area. With a bit of training animals recognise where they are welcome - without having to use physical gates.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Variable

Infill:

Variable

Notes:

The STLs can be printed hull up (requiring few supports) or hull down (requiring lots of support).

The advantage of the latter is that you can control the finish of the top of the finished print using variable processes in Simplify3D; I print quickly with 0.25mm layers at the bottom, tapering down to 0.15mm at the top. Gives a very nice uniform finish. And there is no external surface marred by support removal. Of course there is a lot of internal support to remove...

Printing hull up will leave a shiny finish (from your build plate) on the top of the shell - which you may like. And use very little support material; just a small amount at the down end of the model. This is not a visible area. This approach will leave you with a very clean print internally however. So a matter of taste...

The alternate mount STL version has a bit more depth for the battery (to allow space to stick it to the wall with removable double sided tape) has a 1 layer skirt that you cut off after printing hull down. This is there to provide a lot of hold-down force for the hull as it prints. This is because the dimensional changes in ABS (which I use) pull the print off the print bed as lower layers cool during printing - and you end up with a base that is not precisely flat. Printing hull up does not have this problem (and there is an alt_mount STL for that too), but delivers a shiny top surface. (OK, you can sand it)...

Caveats

Obviously, you will need to be able to get the PCB manufactured. The files are all there to do so and it is very cheap. And of course you need the skills and equipment to source and assemble the electronics!

If you want to use a different buzzer, you will need to make your own shell - but the electronics at least will work for you...

Application

There is a single trimpot to set the length of the beep, once the alarm is triggered. You can also change component values (C1 in particular) to alter the delay before the alarm goes of before triggering the alarm. Set it longer if the system is triggering falsely.

There are pads in the 3D print design at the top and bottom of the Animalarm. Use double sided tape or bluetack at those locations to mount the alarm on the wall / doorway. Or even better, print an alt_mount STL and use removable double sided tape to stick the battery to the wall and then the shell just clips over it and holds itself in place!

How this works

The AnimAlarm uses two PIR (passive infrared) detectors to detect and discriminate between pets and people. The detector needs to be mounted on a door / wall about a meter above the ground. One PIR "looks down", the other "looks up" to detect motion. A pet only triggers the lower detector and sets off the alarm. If a person is detected, the alarm either never triggers or is shut off.

The circuitry is built around a single CMOS chip and a few transistors - and of course battery, buzzer and PIR detectors. The circuitry is incredibly power efficient, drawing less than 30µW normally and only 10mA when triggered. This means alkaline batteries will probably last a year in normal use...

For the product hull / casing, there are two STLs. One is the standard mount version, where you would use the pads at the top and bottom of the hull to affix it to a wall. The alternate mount hull (clearly labelled) is for when you mount the AnimAlarm using the battery holder. You do this by affixing the battery holder to the wall with double-sided tape. There is a neat 3M product that is used for picture hooks that has a tab that, when pulled, removes the tape from the wall. This is perfect in this application. The battery goes on the wall with the tape, and the hull snaps over and is held in place by the battery; very neat.

Electronics

The attached files include:

  • the Eagle design files (schematic and PCB)
  • Circuit schematic
  • PCB layers images
  • Gerber files for the PCB to be produced by seedstudio.com
  • List of special components and their sources

All the components are incredibly cheap; the PIR detectors are less than $2, the circuit board less than $1; indeed the most expensive component is the buzzer. The total component cost is about $15 (printed shell aside)
