title: Layer Fan Duct for MakerParts 3D printer

description.text:
Fan Duct for the MakerParts 3D printer. This one uses a 50mm Radial Fan. The fan itself has 56.7mm between mounting holes, and the output is a rectangle whose exterior dimensions are 19.3mm x 15mm

This thing works wonderfully, and attaches to the heatsink of the E3D v6. You NEED to place kapton tape around the aluminium block of the extruder, otherwise, the fan will cool it down so much the printer will stop extruding!

With this fan duct installed, i was able to print at 200mm/s with no quality loss at all!

Ducto para ventilador de capa para la MakerParts: Este ducto utiliza un ventilador radial de 50mm (el mío lo conseguí en (http://articulo.mercadolibre.com.ar/MLA-655049187-ventilador-radial-turbina-50-mm-12-v-printalot-_JM).
El ventilador radial en sí mismo tiene 56.7mm entre los agujeros de montaje, y la salida de aire tiene 19.3mm x 15mm.

Este ducto funciona maravillosamente, y se sujeta del mismo disipador del hotend E3D v6. Es INDISPENSABLE colocar cinta Kapton (o algún otro aislante térmico) rodeando el bloque de aluminio donde está la punta del hotend, porque sino, al encenderse el ventilador del ducto, la temperatura del hotend cae tanto que es imposible seguir extruyendo!

Con este ducto de capa instalado, es posible imprimir a 200mm/s sin pérdida de calidad de impresión

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/20onCDYCzN1

A shovel and rake style pooper scooper printable on the MakerBot.  Some assembly required.
Rake is 4" Wide, The Shovel is ~7" Wide and there are ergonomic handles that are fun to watch print.
The 7" Shovel base is printed in 5 parts and glued together using ABS pipe cement.

Download the ZIP file (contains 21 files).  Procure two 1/2" Diameter x 24" long dowels, 8 #5 x 1/2" Pan Head Phillips Wood Screws, and a can of ABS pipe cement (used for glueing black ABS drain pipes) from the local hardware store.
For those with larger build platforms (>6.75") the complete shovel base is now uploaded.
Print all the components using ABS (not PLA, so the solvent in the glue works!).
Use the ABS cement to glue the 5 shovel parts together & let dry.
Assemble 2 sets of handles using the 3 handle parts (left & right grip plus the dowel mounting post and 2 #5 screws.  (C-clamps and ABS cement work here as well).
Ream the Dowel holes to 1/2" Diameter as needed.
Insert the dowels into the respective holes and align the handles to the rake and shovel before securing in place.  Either glue or screw into place by drilling  a 1/16" Pilot hole in the ABS and dowel, then 1/8" clearance hole in the abs approximately 1" from the open end of the dowel mounts.  Fasten the dowel in place using one #5 pan head screw in each mount hole.
Paint and/or decorate to your liking.  Happy scooping!

description.text:
I couldn't find a coin counter online that I was happy with. I remembered a set that my Grandma gave me to use when I went to help her at work when I was a child. (Yes, kids used to be welcome in the professional offices back in the day.)

Since there wasn't anything like them online, I decided to make a set.

These coin counters print using support, but with the support settings I used, only the gap at the top of the tube will have support in it and it comes out very easily with the use of a fingernail or thin tool (screwdriver).

The counters are simple to use, just drop coins in the cone until the tube is full, any additional coins will slide out the slot when the tube is full and you tip the counter to the side a bit. About 45 degrees works perfectly.

Once the extra coins are poured out, you can slip the coin wrapper into the tube around the coins, it may take some shaking and turning of the tube and wrapper, but with some practice, it is easy to wrap the coins in just a few seconds.

Printer:

Monoprice Makerselect Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

Notes:

Printed in PLA, but you can print in your flavor of filament.

My Cura settings for the support were as follows:
Support Placement: Everywhere
Support Overhang Angle: 60 Degrees
Support Pattern: ZigZag
Support Density: 15%
Support Z Distance: 0.15 mm
Support X/Y Distance: 1.0 mm

Using the default Cura support settings, Cura created support for the lettering on the tube which should not be needed. A couple of the settings you will probably have to make visible by clicking the gear next to "Support".

print_settings.Notes:: Hobbyking Brown ABS

title: Boat Tiles Remix with OpenLock connectors

description.text:
I loved the Boat tiles by ProffessorChubbs: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2380515
But the connectors were somewhat clunky and so I remixed it with the Openlock connector designs: https://www.printablescenery.com/product/open-lock/
I have altered the clip slightly to be more loose fitting, but it is still cross compatible with all Openlock connectors.

I have not altered the sharp corners.
There is some difficulty printing the rings on the main mast without support (see the picture, two broke).
There is difficulty printing the Helm without support (I have yet to try with support).

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Hobbyking Brown ABS

Removal of in built supports

Remove supports in the female slots. be careful not to remove the thicker supports that are set back a bit, only the ones on the edge of the model.

Overall

I took the originals, Cut off bottom, raised slightly, extruded bottom down, cut out placement for the openlock template and inserted openlock template. Where necessary the openlock template was trimmed.

  • No changes were made to top of the boat tile templates, only base changed.
Railings problem

Due to the small width of the railings then the openlock templates could not fit. these had to be set as a default clip instead (similar choice was made by the original base design)

Openlock clip modifications

Open lock clip was trimmed to reduce height and pins on sides of clip trimmed slightly as well. this is to compensate for contraction when printing in ABS as well as avoid the tiles not lying flat if any warping in sockets.
